name: XML
title: XML

children.text: , you can manage, parse, and bundle XML formatted text.
You do not need to establish a connection to use the XML app.
You can use the following types of modules to build your
Converts a bundle to an XML formatted text.
Describes the structure of the resulting XML.
If you have a sample of the XML you would like to parse, you can use it to generate the data structure:
Copy and paste the XML sample into the
Verify that the data structure has been successfully generated.
A typical use case is to transform data from a Google spreadsheet into XML.

to fetch the data. Setup the module to retrieve rows from your Google spreadsheet and set the Maximum number of returned rows to a small number, but larger than one for testing purposes (e.g. three). Run the
module (right-click it and choose "Run this module only") and verify the output of the module.
module after the Google Sheets module. In the module's setup choose the
module in the Source node field. Leave the other fields as they are for the moment.
r module. The module's setup requires a data structure that describes the structure of the XML output. Click on
to open the data structure setup. The easiest way to create this Data structure is to generate it automatically from an XML sample. Click on
and paste your XML sample to the Sample data field:
. The specification field in the data structure setup should now contain the generated structure.
Change the name of your Data structure to something more specific (e.g. "My XML data structure") and click
. A field corresponding to the root XML element should appear as a mappable field in the XML module's setup.

to close the XML module's setup.
module's field corresponding to the parent XML element. Map items output from the Google Sheets module to appropriate fields.
module should output the correct XML file. Open the setup of the

number to be larger than the number of rows in your spreadsheet to process all the data. The resulting XML can be then saved to Dropbox, sent as an attachment via email, uploaded via FTP to a server, etc.
If you want to add attributes to a complex node (a node, that will contain other nodes), you have to add a collection with the name
for this node in your custom data structure, and this collection will be mapped to node attributes
If you want to add attributes to a text node (example:
), you have to add a collection
for attributes and a text property
for the node value for this node in your custom data structure.
Parses an XML formatted text and outputs a single bundle containing all the information extracted from the XML.
Select or add a date structure.
Describes the structure of the XML to make the output of the module available in the mapping panel for the modules that follow.
If you have a sample of the XML you would like to parse, you can use it to generate the data structure:
Copy and paste the XML sample into the
Verify that the data structure has been successfully generated.

You can skip steps 2-5 to supply an empty data structure. This way the output of the module will not be available in the mapping panel until the module has been executed at least once to process an XML input.
If you use a formula, make sure its result value type is (or can be automatically changed to) Text type. If the result value type is Buffer (binary data) then use
function to convert it to the Text type.
A typical use case is to download an XML file from a URL and parse its content. Here is a step by step guide how to achieve this:
Configure the module. Add the URL of the XML file.
In your web browser, open a new tab/window.
Enter the URL you used in the third step in the address bar and fetch the XML file.
Select all the XML text and copy it into the clipboard.
Close the tab/window and get back to your
Paste the copied XML text into the
Verify that the data structure has been successfully generated.

You can skip these steps to supply an empty data structure. This way the output of the module will not be available in the mapping panel until the module has been executed at least once to process an XML input.

function to convert its value from Buffer (binary data) type to Text type.

module will put attributes in a special collection
as a child of the node that has these attributes. If the node is a text node and it has attributes, then two special properties will be added:
for the text content of the node.

customCSS:
<style>
@media print {
  html, body {
    overflow-x: visible;
  }
}
#tally-widget-button {
  position: fixed !important;
  background-color: #FFFFFF;
  display: none;
  visibility: visible !important;
  opacity: 1 !important;
  color: #0C121D;
  border: 2px solid #0C121D;
  border-radius: 4px;
  align-items: center;
  justify-content: center;
  font-size: 14px;
  font-weight: 600;
  font-family: 'Inter';
  text-align: center;
  box-shadow: 0 4px 6px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.2);
  cursor: pointer;
  z-index: 999999 !important;
  -webkit-tap-highlight-color: transparent;
  outline: none;
  touch-action: manipulation;
  pointer-events: auto;
  transform: translate3d(0, 0, 0);
}
.button-text {
  display: inline-block;
  margin-right: 8px;
}
.button-text::before {
  content: attr(data-text);
}
#tally-widget-popup {
  position: fixed;
  background-color: white;
  display: none;
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 10px 20px rgba(0, 0, 0, 0.4);
  z-index: 999999;
  overflow: hidden;
  border: 0px solid #0C121D;
  padding-top: 30px;
}
#tally-widget-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 10px;
  right: 10px;
  background: none;
  border: none;
  font-size: 36px;
  font-weight: bold;
  padding: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
  color: #0C121D;
}

  .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
    font-family: 'Inter' !important;
  }

  .dark .ab-plugin-wrapper .ab-link-block-item .ab-link {
    color: #F6F6F6 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column > div > div > div.flex.flex-1.w-full.justify-center.pb-0 > div > div.flex.items-center.pl-0.pr-2.mb-5.xl\:-mt-1\.5 > div > div > div > div:nth-child(1) > div.flex.pr-2.text-gray-500.items-center {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  a.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-public-space-links-wrap .ab-public-space-link:first-of-type {
    border-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  .ab-toc-item-active a{
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }

  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
  #main-column .text-ab-blue-500 {
    text-decoration-color: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-left:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-left:hover .ab-nav-left-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  .ab-nav-right:hover > svg,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .text-gray-300,
  .ab-nav-right:hover .ab-nav-right-text {
     color: #7302D5 !important;
     stroke: #7302D5 !important;
  }
  
#tally-inline-popup {
  position: fixed;
  display: none;
  z-index: 999999;
  width: min(420px, 90vw);
  height: min(550px, 80vh);
  background: #fff;
  color: #0c121d;
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.08);
  border-radius: 12px;
  box-shadow: 0 12px 28px rgba(0,0,0,0.22), 0 2px 6px rgba(0,0,0,0.12);
  overflow: hidden;
  padding: 5px;
}

#tally-inline-popup iframe {
  width: 100%;
  height: 100%;
  border: 0;
  display: block;
  border-radius: 8px;
}

#tally-inline-popup .tip-close {
  position: absolute;
  top: 6px;
  right: 8px;
  width: 32px;
  height: 32px;
  line-height: 28px;
  font-size: 22px;
  text-align: center;
  background: rgba(255,255,255,0.85);
  border: 1px solid rgba(0,0,0,0.06);
  border-radius: 8px;
  cursor: pointer;
}

#main-column a[data-form-url],
#main-column a[data-tally-url] {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
  text-decoration: underline;
  text-underline-offset: 2px;
  text-decoration-thickness: 1.5px;
  font-weight: 600;
}

@media (max-width: 640px) {
  #tally-inline-popup {
    width: min(360px, 94vw);
    height: min(500px, 80vh);
  }
}

#main-column .ab-cta-button a.ab-cta-button {
  background-color: #7302D5;
}

/* Titles in purple */
.ab-link-blocks-wrapper .ab-link-block-item.ab-docs-card-mode .ab-link-block-content-wrap .font-bold {
  color: #7302D5 !important;
}

.ab-tree-navigation-link-active span {
    color: #7302D5 !important;
}

</style>

reusableContentVariables.name: string
reusableContentVariables.description: a list or sequence of characters (like letters, numbers, and symbols) used to represent text in a computer programming.

reusableContentVariables.name: Operations
reusableContentVariables.description: An operation is a single module run to process data or check for new data.

reusableContentVariables.name: Credits
reusableContentVariables.description: Credits (formerly operations) are the currency for running scenarios.

reusableContentVariables.name: Route
reusableContentVariables.description: A route is a path that data can flow through in a scenario, visualized as the dotted lines between modules.
